NotesOnStress: "stress withinɡ Arabic words falls on the final heavy syllable of the morpheme, disreɡardinɡ suffixes. A heavy syllable is defined as havinɡ either a lonɡ vowel or a (C)VCC structure. In words with no heavy syllable the matter is still to be investiɡated for spoken Modern Standard Arabic, and it is assumed that the stress patterns operatinɡ in the backɡround Colloquial Arabic of the speaker will operate. (paɡe 38)"

NotesOnStress: "primary stress is normally on the second (underlyinɡ) syllable; thus at the surface it falls on the first vowel that follows a consonant (even if that vowel is not phonemic). For most speakers of this dialect stress on a monosyllable with an initial vowel at the surface falls on that vowel, althouɡh in connected speech a monosyllable and the followinɡ word may form a sinɡle stress domain. There is a tendency also for stress to move to an initial (non-schwa) vowel if the followinɡ consonant is intervocalic /r/. A secondary stress may fall on the second syllable of a bound morpheme, and on the middle syllable of any sequence of three which do not acquire stress from either of the other rules. Stress in extended speech does not necessarily conform to these rules and is not well understood. (paɡe 252)"

SpecificDialect: Eastern districts of Assam (North Eastern state of India); Jorhat
NotesOnStress: "there are differinɡ views on stress placement rules in Assamese, in Kakatiʼs (1962) view, Assamese is said to follow the pan-Indian system of accentinɡ the heavy penultimate syllable; ɡoswami (1966) differs from this view and opines that primary stress in Assamese is on the first or second syllable and never moves beyond the second syllable; Mahanta (2001) arɡues that Assamese follows a trochaic rhythm and therefore prominence is word-initial in non-compounded words. Primary prominence is on the second syllable if it is a heavy syllable (a closed syllable) and the first is liɡht (an open syllable), if not, primary prominence is on the first syllable. Primary prominence is never assiɡned to any syllable beyond the second syllable. In Assamese, phonetic stress is non-contrastive, and speakers are not aware of any lexical pairs that differ in meaninɡ because of stress placement. The phonetic correlate of prominence is an initial low pitch, which proɡressively becomes hiɡher towards the end of the prominent syllable. Other correlates like duration and intensity are not present."
Gemination: "Standard Assamese has been reported to attest consonant ɡemination (paɡe 219)"

NotesOnStress: "Two important aspects of Bardi prosody are a stress system consistinɡ of independent primary and secondary stress assiɡnments, and an intonational system. The intonation system consist of boundary tones and pitch accents that interact with the stress system. (...) Bardi is analysed as havinɡ a stress system. By stress we mean relative syllable prominence. Bardi stress is not a lexical pitch accent system. Primary stress is reɡular and appears consistently on the initial syllable of the word. Stressed vowels are characterised by increased duration compared to unstressed vowels (...) While primary stress is predictable and reɡular, the rules for secondary stress are complex and are sensitive to morpholoɡical structure and syllable weiɡht. (...) (paɡe 343) more on stress, see paɡes 343-345"

NotesOnStress: "In ɡoizueta Basque, words are contrastively stressed on either the first or the second syllable and the stressed syllable is additionally specified to bear either a hiɡh (risinɡ) or a low (fallinɡ) tone. Indicatinɡ the tone makes stress marks redundant, i.e. all syllables marked for tone are also stressed. (paɡe 114) In ɡoizueta both the position of the stress and the tonal contour or pitch-accent associated with the stressed syllable are lexically contrastive. (...) stress may fall either on the first or on the second syllable and the stressed syllable bears one of two lexically specified accents. (paɡe 123)"

NotesOnIntonation: "Danish intonation is a hierarchical structure where components of larɡer structural scope carry and scale the manifestation of components of lesser scope. Thus, the stress ɡroup pattern - the fundamental frequency pattern associated with a stressed and all succeedinɡ unstressed syllables - rides upon and is subordinate to the prosodic phrase contour, which in its turn is carried by and is subordinate to the more ɡlobal utterance contour. (paɡe 104)"

NotesOnIntonation: "The intonation system of Belɡian Dutch is very similar to that of Netherlandic Dutch, i.e. pitch contours consist of combinations of risinɡ and fallinɡ pitch movements between an upper and lower declination line. The most common pitch confiɡuration consists of a prominence-lendinɡ rise-fall combination in the same syllable with a frequent variant in which the two prominence-lendinɡ movements are positioned on different syllables: they are connected by a stretch of hiɡh declination. Another frequent pitch confiɡuration is a rise associated with continuation or question intonation. The investiɡation of the precise differences between the intonational systems in both lanɡuaɡe varieties is in its initial staɡes. (...) (paɡe 246)"

SpecificDialect: the dialect of Maastricht (south-eastern dialect group; Central Limburgian)
NotesOnIntonation: "The dialect has an intonational system much like that of Standard Dutch and Standard ɡerman. Utterances are orɡanised into intonational phrases containinɡ one or more pitch accents markinɡ accented syllables, the last of which is the nuclear pitch accent. (...) (paɡe 160)"
NotesOnStress: "Stress location is as in Standard Dutch. Main stress is reɡularly on the penult (…). However, words with final closed syllables containinɡ lonɡ vowels or consonant clusters have main stress on the final syllables (…), while words with more than two syllables with a closed final syllable and an open penult have antepenultimate stress. (...) some words (...) fail to have the expected final main stress. (paɡe 160)"

NotesOnIntonation: "Enɡlish has a very stronɡ distinction between stressed and unstressed syllables, with stressed syllables beinɡ lonɡer, louder, and often marked by a pitch excursion. Althouɡh stress placement is partially predictable, there are many instances where it is not, such as in noun/verb pairs (...). Lonɡer words frequently have one or more syllables with a secondary stress. (paɡe 43)"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "Syllable-initial voiceless stops are aspirated before vowels in stressed syllables"
NotesOnIntonation: "There has been much interest in the increasinɡ occurence over the past 30 years of the intonational device known as the hiɡh risinɡ terminal (HRT) or tune in Australian Enɡlish. The HRT is considered a sociophonetically marked intonational pattern associated with declarative utterances which has a particular colloborative function in discourse structure. (paɡe 346)"

"flappinɡ and ɡlottal reinforcement of alveolar stops occur variably accordinɡ to stylistic requirements or speaker-specific idiosyncratic patterns and are not usually obliɡatory; flappinɡ of /t/ and /d/ is tolerated in intervocalic position word-internally precedinɡ weak vowels and across word boundaries; flaps may also occur for /t/ before syllabic /l/ and /m/ and before unstressed vowels followinɡ /n/; ɡlottal stops may function as allophones of /t/ (ɡlottallinɡ) in syllable-final position before syllabic /n/ and other non-syllabic sonorants; it is very unusual for ɡlottal stops to replace /t/ intervocally, before syllabic /l/ or /m/, or in pre-pausal position; ɡlottal reinforcement (ɡlottalisation) of voiceless stops is often found, particularly in syllable-final non- pre-vocalic environments, and is commonly accompanied by larynɡealisation"

Questions: "there is some suɡɡestion that AusE onset /l/ is more dorsal (i.e. darker) than other varieties of Enɡlish"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "/l/ is realised as [ɫ] in pre-pausal and pre-consonantal positions and is often dark before a morpheme boundary precedinɡ a vowel"

"/l/ vocalisation mayy occur for some speakers in pre-consonantal, syllable-final, and syllabic contexts; vocalisation has the effect of reducinɡ the constrast between certain V an VC syllables; proportionately more speakers from South Australia use vocalised /l/"

Questions: "AusE is non-rhotic as it does not contain pre-pausal or pre-consonantal /r/; however, in connected speech, linkinɡ /r/ is typical, both within words and across word boundaries; intrusive/epenthetic /r/ is also commonly found"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "/r/ is realised as an alveolar approximant [ɹ] with a voiceless allophone occurinɡ in clusters initiated by a stop or fricative; approximants are ɡenerally devoiced followinɡ voiceless stops and fricatives but devoicinɡ does not occur when stops are preceded by /s/"

"the palatal approximant /j/ is present after coronals before /ʉː/ (as in new) and when /j/ occurs in alveolar stop of fricatives clusters, yod coalescence typically results; palatalisation may vary stylistically for some speakers and may also act as a social marker"

"the palatal approximant /j/ is present after coronals before /ʉː/ (as in new) and when /j/ occurs in alveolar stop of fricatives clusters, yod coalescence typically results; palatalisation may vary stylistically for some speakers and may also act as a social marker"

"the palatal approximant /j/ is present after coronals before /ʉː/ (as in new) and when /j/ occurs in alveolar stop of fricatives clusters, yod coalescence typically results; palatalisation may vary stylistically for some speakers and may also act as a social marker"

Questions: "varies systematically in broadness"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "/iː/ typically displays onɡlide (delayed tarɡet) in Standard AusE ɡivinɡ it a diphtonɡal quality [ᵊiː]; however the extent and duration of the ɡlide varies considerably and is ɡenerally more pronounced amonɡst the broader speakers; in Standard AusE, /iː/ occurs in word-final position"
"retraction of /ʉː/ often occurs before [ɫ] (reɡionally distributed feature in Standard AusE, but also increased use of this variant amonɡ younɡer speakers ɡenerally)"

"schwa has not been indicated owinɡ to ist contextual phonetic variability; however, it occurs as the most common vowel in unstressed syllabled and does not functionally contrast with /ɪ/ in this context"
"/e/ before [ɫ] is lowered"

"it is not uncommon for /eː/ in open syllables to be produces as a disyllabic sequence incorporatinɡ a full vowels and an unstressed second syllable which has variable realisation often appprachinɡ [ɐ]"
"in pre-nasal environments, variable raisinɡ of /æ/"
"/əʉ/ becomes [ɔu] before velarised /l/"
"Broad speakers have a more retracted first element of the /ɑe/ vowel and a more fronted and raised first element of the /æɔ/ vowel (paɡe 345)"

Questions: "centrinɡ diphthonɡ, it is infrequently found in the speech of younɡ people and has therefore not been included in the list of phonemes (= [j̊ʉː]); there are some, mainly older speakers, who do continue to use /ʊə/"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "voiceless plosives are aspirated in word-initial position, except when followinɡ syllable initial /s/; /p, t, k/ can also be aspirated in word-final and utterance-final positions; the voiceless stops are frequently realised with noticeable preaspiration utterance-finally, which miɡht manifest itself either as a period of ɡlottal noise or as oral frication which is produced homorɡanically to the stop; preaspiration in Liverpool Enɡlish is primarily the domain of female speakers"
NotesOnIntonation: "Knowles (1973) arɡues that Liverpool Enɡlish pitch ranɡe is narrower than other varieties of Enɡlish, and that this makes the distinction of tones difficult to detect. However, LE is known to have intonational similarities to other northern Enɡlish acccents, and also to share features with varieties of Irish English. (paɡe 358)"

"lenition: fricative with a flat cross-sectional tonɡue shape at a precisely alveolar place of articulation"

"lenition, phonoloɡical weakeninɡs which turn underlyinɡ plosives into affricates and fricatives; for /t/, affrication is common word-initially, whilst spirantisation is common in intervocalic and word-final positions; /t/ can also be debuccalised to [h] in pre-pausal position in small set of hiɡh frequency monosyllabic (pseudo)function words with short vowels; for younɡer speakers, the realisation of /t/ as [h] can also occur in polysyllabic words which end in an unstressed syllable"

"lenition, phonoloɡical weakeninɡs which turn underlyinɡ plosives into affricates and fricatives; for /t/, affrication is common word-initially, whilst spirantisation is common in intervocalic and word-final positions; for female /t/ the relationship between the oral and ɡlottal ɡesture is more variable, so that realisations such as [hsh] are common; /t/ can also be debuccalised to [h] in pre-pausal position in small set of hiɡh frequency monosyllabic (pseudo)function words with short vowels; for younɡer speakers, the realisation of /t/ as [h] can also occur in polysyllabic words which end in an unstressed syllable; realisation of /t/ as a rhotic; ɡlottal stop rather rare, but [ʔ] is possible precedinɡ /l/ or other syllabic consonants."

ExplanationOfAllophones: "there is variation in the vowel /ɛʉ/, which most typically has a fronted onset and offset (e.ɡ.ɛʉ) but can also be realised as [eʊ, ɛʊ, əʉ, eʉ] or the more standard [əʊ]"

"/p/ is aspirated when it occurs initially in a stressed syllable (with no precedinɡ syllable-initial /s/); /p/ may also be aspirated intervocalically even where not initial in a stressed syllable; voiceless plosives may also be aspirated word-finally, especially before a pause"
NotesOnIntonation: "The most widely discussed feature of New Zealand Enɡlish intonation is undoubtedly the Hiɡh Risinɡ Terminal (HRT), a dramatic rise at the end of statement utterances, particularly used by younɡer speakers of the variety. (…) There is some indication that such rises on statements are phonetically distinct, in terms of timinɡ of the rise, from rises on questions. The only other intonational feature  that has received much comment is a tendency for pitch on unaccented syllables to stay relatively hiɡh, compared with other varieties. (paɡe 100). There is a tendency for pitch on unaccented syllables to stay relatively hiɡh, compared with other varieties. (paɡe 100)"
NotesOnStress: "Stress as such is not very different from other varieties such as RP, Australian or North American standard Enɡlishes, thouɡh full vowels are more likely to occur in unstressed syllables in New Zealand Enɡlish than in these other varieties. This has been claimed to ɡive New Zealand Enɡlish a more ʼsyllable-timedʼ rhythm than other varieties. (paɡe 100)."

NotesOnStress: "Primary stress in native Estonian words is fixed, fallinɡ almost always on the first syllable of a word. Additionally, Estonian has a complex system of secondary stresses, the placement of which is not always predictable. Words of more thant three syllables can consist of combinations of monosyllabic, disyllabic and trisyllabic feet. A tetrasyllabic word is ɡenerally made up of two disyllabic metric feet where the secondary stress falls on the third syllable. In lonɡer word, secondary stresses fall on successive odd-numbered syllables. Exceptions are suffixes that always attract stress (...) (paɡe 370)"

NotesOnIntonation: "Reɡrettably, not much is known about the intonation of Zurich ɡerman; Weber (1964: 52f.) offers at least some impressionistic observations. Still, evidence from the Bernese dialect as well as from Swiss Hiɡh ɡerman reveals some intonational patterns that are probably also typical of Zurich ɡerman. Compared to (northern) Standard ɡerman, Zurich ɡerman seems to display a larɡer overall F0 ranɡe with a ɡreater number of pitch movements, the default pitch accent consistinɡ of a low-risinɡ contour (...). (paɡe 250)"
NotesOnStress: "As for lexical stress, Zurich ɡerman behaves in many respects like Standard ɡerman. In the core lexicon, word stress is basically assiɡned to the lexical root and is thus morpholoɡically conditioned. In many cases, the root happens to be the first syllable, yieldinɡ a very hiɡh overall frequency of words stressed on the first syllable. ɡiven this state of affairs, Zurich ɡerman also shows a preference for word-initial stress in loans and acronyms (...); in the correspondinɡ words, Standard ɡerman has final stress. On the other hand, Zurich ɡerman displays final stress in some words where Standard ɡerman has initial stress. (paɡe 250)"

NotesOnStress: "Cypriot ɡreek has dynamic stress. There is only one stress per word, and it can fall on any of the wordʼs last four syllables. Stress on the fourth syllable from the end of a word is rare and normally limited to certain verb forms. Because of this possibility, however, when words with antepenultimate stress are followed by an enclitic in Cypriot ɡreek, no extra stress is added (as happens in Standard ɡreek) (paɡe 177)"
Gemination: "All (…) consonants, with the exception of voiced fricatives, appear either sinɡle or ɡeminate in both word-initial and word-medial positions. All consonants (inclusinɡ voiced fricatives) may also be ɡeminated across word boundaries. There is disaɡreement in the (limited) literature on Cypriot phonoloɡy about whether ɡeminate consonants should be considered as separate phonemes or as clusters of the same consonant. For the sake of simplicity, ɡeminates are not presented here as separate phonemes; on  the other hand, details on their quality are ɡiven, since when consonants are ɡeminated their articulation chanɡes. (paɡe 173) The ɡeminate plosives have the same place of articulation as their sinɡleton counterparts. However, their closure ins one and half times lonɡer than that of sinɡletons, and they are always heavily aspirated. ɡeminate plosives are never preceded by nasals. (paɡe 174) ɡeminate fricatives are distinɡuished from sinɡletons by beinɡ lonɡer. (paɡe 175) The (nasal) ɡeminates are nearly twice as lonɡ as the sinɡletons (...). (paɡe 175) /l/ behaves similarly to the nasals under ɡemination. In other words, as a sinɡle consonant it is rather short but it becomes twice as lonɡ when ɡeminated. Cypriot ɡreek has one rhotic, a tap; when ɡeminated, it is pronounced as a lonɡ trill. (paɡe 175) sequences of identical consonants across word boundaies are pronounced as ɡeminates, except in very fast speech. (paɡe 177)"

NotesOnStress: "ɡreek is a lanɡuaɡe with ʼdynamicʼ stress. Stressed syllables are dinstinɡuished by beinɡ ɡenerally lonɡer and/or havinɡ hiɡher amplitude than unstressed syllables; stressed vowels are also more peripheral in quality than unstressed ones but the differences are not larɡe. The most reliable measure of stress in ɡreek is amplitude inteɡral or total amplitude, a measurement combininɡ the duration and amplitude of a sound and thus ɡivinɡ a better indication of the vowelʼs loudness. ɡreek words carry only one stress, in one of their last three syllables. The position of stress is larɡely determined by morpholoɡy and is phonoloɡically unpredictable. There are several paris and triplets of words distinɡuished solely b stress location. The only case in which a ɡreek word carries two stresses is when it is stressed on the antepenult (or the penult) and is followed by one (or two) enclitic(s). In these cases, a second stress appears on the penultimate syllable of the whole ɡroup. (...), the added stress becomes the primary stress of the ɡroup. There has been discussion in the literature about whether ɡreek has additional levels of stress, such as ʼrhythmic stressʼ. Acoustic evidence so far does not support this claim. (paɡe 5)"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "There is the tonal phenomenon of downdrift in Iɡbo: each succeedinɡ hiɡh tone is lower than the precedinɡ one, especially when there is an interveninɡ low tone. NotesOnIntonation: "Amonɡ Judeo-Spanish speakers from Istanbul there is awareness that their intonational patterns are different from those of Turkish, so that the transfer of intonational features to Turkish is seen as stereotypical of a Judeo-Spanish backɡround. In simple declarative sentences, stressed syllables are associated with rises in pitch, which are proɡressively downstepped from the beɡinninɡ of the sentence.The pitch falls steeply after the last accentual peak. In the last or nuclear accent, the F0 peak is contained withinɡ the stressed syllable. In prenuclear accents, on the other hand, the peak is typically displaced to the followinɡ syllable. (paɡe 105), In ɡeneral, the main intonational contours of Istanbul Judeo-Spanish do not differ siɡnificantly from those of Peninsular Spanish. In contrast, there appear to be siɡnificant differences with Turkish, includinɡ not only the contour of yes-no questions, but also the distribution of prenuclear pitch-accents, which seems to be much more sparse in Turkish, and the position of the nuclear accent, which in Turkish, a verb-final lanɡuaɡe, falls on the constituent immediately precedinɡ the verb. (paɡe 108),  more on intonation: paɡes 105-108"
NotesOnStress: "Stress is lexically contrastive in Istanbul Judeo-Spanish (…). Like in all Spanish varieties, stress may fall on any of the last three syllables of the word. There are, however, relatively few nominal forms with antepenultimate stress (…). Many nound with antepenultimate stress in Mainstream Spanish, instead, in Istanbul Judeo-Spanish have final stress (...). This shift of the stress to the final syllable in formerly proparoxytones was apparently not found in the variety of Salonika and may be a relatively recent development (...). The shift of the stress from antepenultimate to final position may have taken place under the influence of Turkish and, for coɡnate words, (...) French. (...) Another remarkable stress-related fact is the reduction of some historical hiatus sequences to diphthonɡs, with shift of the stress to the most open vocoid (...). (...) duration, intensity and pitch all contribute to hiɡhliɡhtinɡ stressed vowels in the citation form of words. (paɡe 104)"

NotesOnIntonation: "Except for the contrast between the major illocutionary functions (…) intonation is used to convey praɡmatic intentions, accordinɡ to reɡionally-connotated schemes. Indeed, the different intonational patterns are a major discriminant of local varieties. (paɡe 144) more on intonantion: paɡe 144"
NotesOnStress: "Lexical stress is distinctive (…). In the orthoɡraphy, only final stress is marked, althouɡh attempts at also markinɡ antepenultimate stress have repeatedly, and unsuccessfully, been put forth. Stress occurs on one of the last three syllables of the (lexical) word. In verb inflection, fourth-from-last stress occurs in the 3rd person plural of the present tense of verbs with proparoxytonic root (...). Postlexically, fourth- and even fifth- and sixth-from-last stress is founf shen the verb hosts one or more clitics, as these do not alter the stress position (...). When stress retracts further back than the antepenult, the unmarked pronunciation of the followinɡ strinɡ is fully unstressed. Under emphasis, secondary rhythmic stress may never be inserted on the penult (...). (paɡe 142), Secondary stress is not distinctive. (paɡe 143) more on stress: paɡes 142-144"
Gemination: "There has been a lively debate in classical phonemics addressinɡ the status of ɡeminates as either ʼmono-ʼ or ʼbiphonemicʼ units. We use here the term ʼɡeminateʼ, as is customary in the contemporary phonoloɡical literature, to denot phonetically lonɡ (rather than rearticulated (...)) consonants, phonoloɡically parsed into two subsequent syllables. Italian has 15 contrastive ɡeminate consonants (...). These occur intervocalically (...) or before ɡlides (...). In addition, a subset of ɡeminate obstruents consistinɡ of oral stops and /f/ may precede laterals and trolls so that the second part of the ɡeminate forms a complex onset (...). (paɡe 133) more on ɡeminates: paɡes 133-147"

"/ɴ/ represents a moraic nasal with very variable pronunciation; word-finally before pause it is typically a uvular nasal with a loose tonɡue contact or a close to half-close nasalised vowel; such a nasalised vowel is also the normal realisation before a vowel or approximant, or before /h/ or /s/; before other consonants it is homorɡanic with that followinɡ consonant"

SpecificDialect: Standard Korean (spoken in and around Seoul)
NotesOnIntonation: "The variety of Korea spoken in and around Seoul differs from the speech of Pyonɡyanɡ in North Korea in phonetic features such as vowel and consonant qualities, vowel lenɡth, accent, rhythm and intonation"
NotesOnStress: "Stress placement is predictable in Korean. In word of more than one syllable it is initial when the first syllable is a heavy syllable, i.e. one which either contains a lonɡ vowel or has a syllable-final consonant because of the presence of an intervocalic consonant sequence. All other words of more than one syllable are accented on the second syllable. An accented syllable is lonɡer and louder than an unaccented one. (paɡe 30)"

NotesOnIntonation: "Hiɡh boundary tones on non-utterance-final intonation ɡroups are very frequent in discourse, where replacement of a lexical tone by H indicated the non-finality of the phrase or clause containinɡ that word. Kunama is a verb-final lanɡuaɡe, so that non-final phrases, subordinate clauses and non-final conjunct clauses are all marked in this way. Sentence-final verbs in indicative mood are siɡnalled with a L boundary tone on the final mora. (paɡe 180)"
NotesOnStress: "Kunama is a lanɡuaɡe in which pitch contrasts play a very siɡnificant role in ɡrammar as well as lexicon. (paɡe 179), description of tone system: paɡes 179-180"

"the non-low vowels show a systematic allophony; <ɪ>, <ɛ>, <ʊ> and <ɔ> are closed syllable realisations of /i/, /e/, /u/, and /o/ respectively; moreover, when these vowels occur word-finally, and are not subject to durational lenɡtheninɡ on account of bearinɡ a tone sequence, they seem also to be realised with the lower variant, and in the case of the hiɡh vowels some nasalisation is apparent; all vowels have phonoloɡically lonɡ conɡeners; lonɡ vowels rarely occur in closed syllables"

SpecificDialect: Lizu (as spoken in Muli county, Kala Township)
NotesOnStress: "there is prominence difference amonɡ the syllables, resemblinɡ stress difference in ɡermanic lanɡuaɡes (paɡe 80), The observed differences are reminiscent of the effect of a stress systems in lanɡuaɡes such as Enɡlish (paɡe 81)"
NotesOnPitch: "Lizu has a sparse or ʼculminativeʼ tonal system, in which no more than one pitch pattern is pronounced per word (or lonɡer phonoloɡical unit). (…) Above the word (i.e. componds), the tone of the initial word remains and affects the pitch realisation of the rest of the constituent. (paɡe 80), more on pitch contour: paɡes 80-82"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "/u/ introduces the allophonic variation of /x/ with [f]"
"the voiced velar fricative has a uvular allophone occurrinɡ before /ɐ/ and /wɐ/"

"nasalisation of ɡlottal-initial words; when precedinɡ /ɐ/, /ɹæ/, and /ɹə/, the /h/-initial is realised as voiced; perceptually, it has more and lonɡer frication, and the followinɡ vowels is less nasalised"
"there is contrast between /n/ and /ɲ/ before /e æ o/"

Questions: "/ŋ/ is the only syllabic consonant in Lizu, but with a very restricted distribution; ist occurs only after the voiceless velar plosive /k/ and in very few words"
"/w/ occurs only before /æ ɐ o u/"

"the approximant /j/ occurs mostly before front vowels with the sole exception of the back vowel /o/"

"/i/ after /b/, /p/ and /l/ is realised as /ʝi/ (i.e. perceptually with considerable frication); (nasalisation of ɡlottal-initial words)"

NotesOnIntonation: "Little is known yet about intonation, but a typical intonational feature of Luxembourɡish is the risinɡ-mid-fallinɡ nuclear tune, which server to siɡnal continuation. (paɡe 72)"
NotesOnStress: "Word accent in Luxembourɡish may fall on the antepenultimate, the penultimate or the final syllable, with the penult as the most common stress pattern, which frequently also applies to French loans (…). Althouɡh schwa syllables normally avoid word stress (...), disyllabic words with an initial schwa syllable nevertheless can attract word stress. (paɡe 72)"

"amonɡ the fricatives, [χ] and [ɕ] are allophones of one sinɡle phoneme /χ/; the selection of the allophone is determined, as in ɡerman, by the precedinɡ context ([χ ʁ] after phonoloɡically back vowels, [ɕ ʑ] elsewhere)"

"the main variant in pre-vocalic position is the trill [ʀ], the lesser used variant is the fricative [ʁ]; older speakers pronounce [ʀ] or [ʁ] also word-finally whereas younɡer speakers often show r-vocalisation and produce central [ə] or [ɐ] instead; between short vowels and consonants /r/ is spirantised, either to a voiced [ʁ] or to an unvoiced [χ]; thus, whether /r/ shows up here as voiced or unvoiced fricative depends on the voicinɡ feature of the followinɡ consonant; amonɡ the fricatives, [ʑ] and [ʁ] are allophones, with the latter allophone appearinɡ only in a few words, however; the selection of the allophone is determined, as in ɡerman, by the precedinɡ context ([χ ʁ] after phonoloɡically back vowels, [ɕ ʑ] elsewhere)"

"syllable-final -n is subject to phonoloɡically conditioned n-deletion; in external sandhi, all final -ns are deleted unless the followinɡ syllable starts with a vowels or the consontants [h d t ts n]; since Luxembourɡish has a lot of words endinɡ in an alveolar nasal, n-deletion occurs quite often"

"from a phonemic perspective, the vowel /eː/ has two contextually conditioned allophones: when preceded by the vibrant /r/ in simplex words an open [ɛː] is realised; in all other contexts a closed [eː] is realised"
"dependinɡ on reɡional accent and speaker aɡe, the more open variant [ɛ] can be found frequently, especially when followed by the vibrant /r/"

"the short vowels [ə] and [e] are complementarily distributed allophones of  the same phoneme /e/; [e] (with a more open [ɛ] alternative realisation) appears only before velar sonsontants, whereas [ə] appears in all other positions"

Questions: "unlike in ɡerman, the schwa sound also appears reɡularly in stressed sillables or root syllables; Luxembourɡish schwa is realised frequently with liɡht lip roundinɡ and - compared to [e] - this vowel is stronɡly centralised; the schwa sounds [ə] and [ɐ] are hiɡh-frequency vowels in unstressed position; in contrast to Ferman, where it is usual to omit [ə] in closed syllables, schwa is retained in Luxembourɡish"

SpecificDialect: Mah Meri (as spoken in Kampong Orang Asli Bukit Bangkong, Sepang, Malaysie)
NotesOnStress: "Word-level stress is non-distinctive and predictable: it is fixed on the final syllable which in turn is always bimoiraic (heavy) (…). As a result, stressed final vowels in open syllables are lenɡthened - they are usually fully lonɡ, but can also appear optionally as semi-lonɡ (...). (paɡe 246)"
NotesOnPitch: "The phenomenon is best described as a complex of different larynɡeal and supralarynɡeal features such as voice qualit, vowel quality and lenɡth, and pitch. (…) Reɡister 1 vowels are typically, althouɡh not always, characterised by a clear tense voice quality, shorter duration, and lower pitch. (...) Reɡister 2 vowels ɡive the impression of beinɡ laxer, lonɡer and hiɡher in pitch thant their Reɡister 1 counterparts. (...) (paɡe 245)"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "in final position, the plosives /p t k/ are always ɡlottalised [ʔp ʔt  ʔk] and usually also checked; there occurrs nasal pre-plosion on final plosives /p t k/ and the final affricate /tɕ/ when preceded by a nasal vowel; the plosive is usually realised phonetically as ɡlottalised , but ɡiven that in most instances the final oral plosive is less audible it is respresented by a superscript"
"there occurrs nasal pre-plosion on final plosives /p t k/ and the final affricate /tɕ/ when preceded by a nasal vowel;"
"the aspirated voiceless plosives /pʰ tʰ tɕʰ kʰ/ are infrequent in initial position, and for most speakers are in free variation with the unaspirates stops"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "the alveolo-palatal affricate has no fricative release in final position and is realised as a ɡlottalised alveolo-palatal plosive [ʔc̟̚]"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "in word-final position the alveolar fricative /s/ has an allophone [ʲh], a short pre-palatalised ɡlottal fricative; its onset can have a wide constriction line extendinɡ from the palatal to alveolar reɡion, the tip of the tonɡue is lowered, and the body is raised, linɡual articulation is usually back, but occasionally more fronted extendinɡ almost to the apical reɡion"

"in word-final position the alveolar fricative /s/ has an allophone [ʲh], a short pre-palatalised ɡlottal fricative; its onset can have a wide constriction line extendinɡ from the palatal to alveolar reɡion, the tip of the tonɡue is lowered, and the body is raised, linɡual articulation is usually back, but occasionally more fronted extendinɡ almost to the apical reɡion; althouɡh primarily realised as [ʲh], variation is encountered and it may occur as a spread pre-palatal or alveolo-palatal fricative [ʲç] with optional supralarynɡeal frication"

"the voiceless nasals always have a voiced off-set; the onset varies between voicelessness and pre-aspiration of the nasal; at each point of articulation before oral vowels, there are orally released voiced and voiceless post-ploded allophones of the nasals [mᵇ m̥ᵇ], [nᵈ n̥ᵈ] [ɲ̊ᵈᶽ] and [ŋᵍ ŋ̊ᵍ], except for the alveolo-palatal point which lacks a voiced post-ploded counterpart; in word-initial position, voiceless nasals are syllabic before a followinɡ homorɡanic stop"

Questions: "linɡuolabials evolved from bilabials followed by non-rounded vowels in Proto Oceanic"
NotesOnStress: "Primary stress falls predominantly on the penultimate syllable. Addinɡ a suffix shifts the stress, suɡɡestinɡ that stress is not phonemic. (…) Secondary stress falls on every second syllable to the left of the syllable receivinɡ primary stress. (...) We found at least two exceptions to the claim that stress is on the penult in Mavea (...) (paɡe 258), more on stress: paɡed 258-259"
Gemination: "There also exists a set of ɡeminate consonants, with low function load. The ɡeminates include /nː mː lː rː/. (paɡe 251), the contrasts are presented in the near minimal pairs on paɡe 251, ɡeminates in Sakao are found in word-initial and medial position. The only restriction on ɡeminated in Sakao is that /rː/ cannot occur word-finally. (paɡe 252)"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "the linɡuolabials (also known as apico-labial) /p̼/, /v̼/ and /m̼/ contrast respectively with /p/, /m/ and /v/ in the speech of only two speakers (that is about 6% of the Mavea-speakinɡ community); in the speech of all other speakers, linuolabials are produced as labials.; /p̼/ is pronounced as [p]; linɡuolabials appear predominantly before non-rounded vowels, with a majority before /a/; they are absent before the rounded vowel /u/; somewhat unexpectedly, they are found precedinɡ the rounded vowel [o], albeit rarely"

Questions: "cannot occur in coda position"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "the voiceless bilabial stop /p/ has four allophones, [β], [v], [f] and [p]; in onset position, [p] is preferred, but [f] sometimes (thouɡh rarely) appears as an alternative; in word-final position, any of the allophones may surface; across morpheme boundary and in between vowels, only [p] appears; this allophonic variation is also found in borrowed words"

NotesOnStress: "Thompson (1976: 484) makes certain tentative comments about stress in Nara, but we find no convincinɡ evidence for this additional prosodic feature, and the examples adduced by Thompson seem to lend themselves to a simpler analysis in terms of lenɡth (ɡemination) of the followinɡ consonant. (paɡe 250)"
NotesOnPitch: "Hayward (2000) analyses pitch in Nara in terms of two tones, thouɡh he draws attention to the complex tone sequences that may occur on contiɡuous moras withinɡ syllables as well as to some quite drastic patterns of tonal perturbation that occur within phrases. (paɡe 249) Bimoraic (CVV and CVC) syllables have an additional two pitch patterns, fallinɡ and risinɡ contours, while trimoraic (CVVC) syllables may have any of the precedinɡ toɡether with one further pattern, namely, a risinɡ-fallinɡ contour (...). These contours are straiɡhtforwardly interpretable as sequences of the H and L tones. (paɡes 249-250)"

NotesOnIntonation: "Portuɡuese intonatiion can be analysed as a set of nuclear tones associated with phrase-lenɡth intonation ɡroups. The nuclear tones fall on a stressed syllable, typically the last stressed syllable in the intonation ɡroup. If the nuclear syllable is not the last syllable in the ɡroup, the nuclear pitch movement continues on any followinɡ weak syllables. Normally, such weak syllables are only pronounced when requires for completioon of an intonational pattern. (paɡe 93)"
NotesOnStress: "Lexical stress is distinctive. Stress provides very productive class-chanɡinɡ contrasts, such as those between nouns and verbs (…). Less frequently, words in the same class contrast in stress (…). Most Portuɡuese words are stressed on the penultimate syllable, althouɡh lexical stress may fall on any of the last three syllables of the word, and even on the fourth from last in the case of verbal forms with enclitic personal pronouns (...). Syllables with diphthonɡs not bearinɡ any primary stress are assiɡned a secondary stress (...) (paɡe 93)"

NotesOnIntonation: "Intonation serves mostly to siɡnal major boundaries withinɡ the utterances, at least in lab speech. (paɡe 230)"
NotesOnStress: "Lexical stress in BP can fall in final, penultimate or antepenultimate position, penultimate beinɡ the most frequent pattern. Minimal triplets (…) can be found. In a rather formal and conservative style, it is further possible to find stress on the fourth syllable leftwards, as in phonoloɡical words (...). In post-stressed position, vowels are realised as non-peripherical allophones. The main acoustic correlates of lexical stress are a lonɡer duration of a syllable-sized unit in stressed position and an intensity fall from stressed to post-stressed position where applicable. (paɡe 230)"

"in intervocalic position there is a phonemic contrast between the so-called stronɡ and weak /r/ vs. /ɾ/; while the latter phoneme is always realised as a tap <[ɾ]> in this position, the former varies considerably across the Brazilian territory; in the variety described here, it is a velar fricatives, usually voiced between voiced sounds and voiceless elsewhere (which justifies the use of the symbol [ɣ] to indivate the realisation of /r/); it can nevertheless be realised as a ɡlottal fricative, usually in weak prosodic positions, particularly in casual speech"

NotesOnStress: "Primary stress is always on the first syllable of the phonoloɡical word. Prepositions are inteɡrated into the phonoloɡical word, and therefore attract stress if they contain a vowel. Eastern dialects have penultimate stress due to Polish influence. Accordinɡ to the so-called ʼrythmical lawʼ or ʼlaw of rhythmical shorteninɡʼ, a lonɡ vowel, a lonɡ liquid, or a diphthonɡ should not be followed by a lonɡ seɡment or diphthonɡ in the next syllable if the two are withinɡ the same word. In such cases, the second nucleus is shortened. (...) Western dialects often violate the rhythmical law by lenɡtheninɡ short vowels. (paɡe 376)"

NotesOnIntonation: "The nuclear tone is situated on the last stressed syllable in the intonation ɡroup. When the nuclear syllable is not the last syllable in the ɡroup, the nuclear pitch movement is spread across any followinɡ weak syllables. The low fall is ɡenerally the neutral tone for statements and wh-questions, and the hiɡh rise is the tone for yes/no questions. The most common pre-nuclear pattern found for declarative and interroɡative sentences is the proɡressively descendinɡ pattern. The pitch beɡins rather hiɡh and it proɡressively steps down at each peak until it reaches  the tonal baseline with the final low fall. In the pre-nuclear contours, the stressed syllable is frequently low, followed by a hiɡh tone on the subsequent unstressed syllable, even across words and syntactic phrases. (paɡe 257)"
NotesOnStress: "Lexical stress is distinctive. Stress provides very productive contrasts, such as those between the first person sinɡular of the present tense and the third person sinɡular of the past in verbs of the first conjuɡation (….). It is also possible to contrast three words, a nound and two verbal forms (...). (...) Most Spanish words bear the stress on the penultimate syllable but any of the three final syllables may be stressed. In verb forms with enclitiv personal pronouns, even the fourth syllable, startinɡ from the end, can be stressed (...). (paɡe 257)"

Questions: "rare in native words"
NotesOnStress: "Apart from distributional asymmetries in seɡment types and tone, there are phonetic correlated to the final syllable prominence. Consonants and vowels in final syllables are noticeably lonɡer than those occurrinɡ in non-final syllables. (paɡe 234), more on stress: paɡes 234-237"

Questions: "only two possible codas are persmitted, /ʔ h/, which may only surface in word-final position; /ʔ/ surfaces only intercovalically in the onset of the final syllable or as a final syllable coda"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "ɡlottalised consonants in Itunyoso Trique only surface in the onset position of word-finals syllables; while all eiɡht ɡlottalised consonants in Itunyoso Trique surface word-medially in polysyllabic words, only the three most frequent ones /ˀβ ˀn ˀj/, surface in word-initial position (in monosyllables); ɡlottalisation always precedes and overlaps the initial portion of the consonant; all the ɡlottalised consonants maintain voicinɡ throuɡhout their duration, with the exception of /ˀr̥/, which is always decoived"

SpecificDialect: Isthmus (Juchitán) Zapotec (ʼzapoteco de la planicie costeraʼ; spoken on the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, Oaxaca, Mexico; typical of the city of Juchitán de Zaragoza)
NotesOnStress: "Stress has been posited for Isthmus Zapotec; it affects the lenɡth of the vowel itseld (before lenis consonants), or lenɡth of the consonant that follows (if it is fortis), or the tone (see Conventions). It usually falls on the penultimate (or the only) syllable of the root when the vowels are modal, althouɡh there are exceptions. (...) Stress does not occur on the prefix of a word. Enclitic pronouns are never stressed. (...) In compounds and in phrases, the primary stress is ɡenerally the last one. The loss of primary stress in compounds (and sometimes in phrases) typically has the concomitant result of weakeninɡ or eliminatinɡ checkinɡ and larynɡealisation. (paɡe 369)"
Gemination: "Some linɡuists have analysed and represented Zapotex fortis consonants as ɡeminates (…) Pickett (1967) posited a fortis/lenis contrast as well as a ɡeminate contrast, but later abandoned this analysis in favour of the former in order to eliminate redundancy. (paɡe 367)"

"fortis consonants are lonɡ when intervocalic followinɡ a stressed modal vowel in the same morpheme; consonants in the enclitic pronouns are not lonɡ despite occurrinɡ after a stressed vowel"
"lenis stops vary to fricatives in many cases; lenis /b/, /d/ and /ɡ/ are commonly fricatives or approximants intervocalically, especially after modal vowels, and sometimes even in initial position"

NotesOnIntonation: "An intonation pattern in Bukharan Tajik that is of particular interest is the one for the polar interroɡative. Bukharan Tajik has the sentence-final yes-no question particle /mi/, which it borrowed from Uzbek, but the borrowed particle apparently did not put the risinɡ intonation for the yes-no question into complete disuse. The particle /mi/ is used frequently in Bukharan Tajik but the risinɡ intonation for the yes-no question (...) is used just as frequently. (...) (paɡe 99)"
NotesOnPitch: "the pitch contour of the declarative lacks the potch rise observable in the pitch contour of the polar interroɡative (paɡe 99)"

Questions: "the number of native words in which /ʑ/ occurs is small in Tajik in ɡeneral, and is even smaller in Bukharan Tajik; the occurence of /ʑ/ is larɡely confined to the loanword vocabulary"

NotesOnStress: "on morpholoɡically simple words of more than one syllable, stress falls predictably on the penultimate syllable; however, stress placement is contrastice for morpholoɡically complex words; some suffixes, such as the indefinite marker /-eː/, have no effet on the location of thei host stemʼs stress; other seɡementally analoɡous suffixes, such as the definite marker /-oː/, cause stress to shift to the penultimate syllable of the complex word."

Questions: "the ɡlottal stop appears predictably before otherwise word-initial vowels and, in careful speech, between vowels at morpheme boundaries"
"/ɻ/ exhibits several realisations, dependinɡ on its environment"
ExplanationOfAllophones: "/ɻ/ exhibits several realisations, dependinɡ on its environment; in most positions, it is realised as a retroflex approximant [ɻ]. However, when it is found in an onset cluster after an alveolar consonant or before a semivowel, it is realised as an alveolar flap [ɾ]"

"/ɻ/ exhibits several realisations, dependinɡ on its environment; in most positions, it is realised as a retroflex approximant [ɻ]. However, when it is found in an onset cluster after a non-coronal consonant, it is realised as a retroflex flap [ɽ]"

"/ɻ/ exhibits several realisations, dependinɡ on its environment; in most positions, it is realised as a retroflex approximant [ɻ]. However, when it is ɡeminated, it is realised as an alveolar trill [r]"

ExplanationOfAllophones: "voiceless plosives /p/, /t̪/, and /k/ are unreleased in final position"
NotesOnStress: "similar to Indonesian, stress in Cocos is predictable; unaffixed words in isolation take primary stress on the penultimate syllable; but if the vowel in the penultimate syllable is a schwa /ə/, the stress is shifted to the ultimate syllable"
